clinical_notes.note: Pt here for his quarterly check-up for his chronic conditions. Reports good medication adherence. No new complaints. Denies chest pain, SOB, or palpitations. Blood pressure in office is 138/86 mmHg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Will continue with current medication regimen. Discussed the importance of diet and exercise in managing his DM2 and HTN.

Follow-up visit for HTN management. Pt reports occasional dizziness, especially when standing up too quickly. BP today is 130/82 mmHg. Reviewed his home BP log, which shows readings are consistently in the 130s/80s. Encouraged him to continue monitoring and to rise slowly from a seated or lying position. No changes to his lisinopril at this time.

Pt presents with c/o increased thirst and frequent urination over the past 2 weeks. Fingerstick glucose in office is 250 mg/dL. A1c drawn today. Suspect his DM2 is not well-controlled. Pt admits to some dietary indiscretions recently. Counseled on the importance of adhering to his diabetic diet. Will await A1c results before making any medication adjustments.

Pt here for routine asthma follow-up. Reports her symptoms are well-controlled with her current inhaler regimen. No recent exacerbations. Denies wheezing or SOB. Lung function tests today are within normal limits. Will continue with her current treatment plan.

Pt called the office with c/o increased wheezing and coughing over the past few days. Symptoms are worse at night. Has been using her rescue inhaler more frequently. Suspect a mild asthma exacerbation, possibly triggered by seasonal allergies. Advised her to start a short course of oral steroids and to follow up if her symptoms do not improve.

Pt here for her regular GAD follow-up. Reports feeling more anxious lately, which she attributes to the start of the new school year. Denies any panic attacks. We discussed coping strategies and relaxation techniques. She feels her current medication is still effective, but we will consider a small dose increase if her symptoms worsen.

Pt here for his semi-annual cardiology follow-up. Reports he has been feeling well and has been able to maintain his usual level of activity without any chest pain or SOB. EKG today shows he is in his baseline AFib. Will continue with his current medication regimen.

Pt presents to the ED with c/o worsening SOB and a 5-pound weight gain over the past week. On exam, he has 2+ pitting edema in his lower extremities and crackles in the bases of his lungs. BNP is elevated. Admitted for a CHF exacerbation.

Pt has responded well to IV diuretics. His weight is down by 6 pounds, and his SOB has resolved. He will be discharged home tomorrow on an increased dose of his diuretic. Will need to follow up with cardiology in 1 week.

Pt here for a routine follow-up for her Crohn's disease. She has been in remission for the past 6 months on her current medication. Denies any abdominal pain, diarrhea, or other symptoms. Will continue with her current treatment plan.

Pt calls the office with c/o a flare-up of her Crohn's symptoms, including abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea. She has been under a lot of stress at work, which she feels may have triggered this flare. Will start her on a course of oral steroids and have her come in for an office visit next week.

Pt has responded well to the steroid taper and is now back in remission. We discussed long-term management options, including the possibility of starting a biologic medication to help prevent future flares. Pt is hesitant to start a new medication at this time but will consider it if she has another flare-up.
